They will redraw the district so that the lines of the district, you know, just like the United States is separated up in the Straits of states and it looks all nice and formal. They will read all rather lines of the district. So at the houses of the people that vote for their party will all
All Arguments Summarized:
1. The text discusses the practice of gerrymandering in political districts.
2. This occurs when a political party, in control of redrawing district lines, manipulates those lines to benefit their party.
3. They do this by concentrating opposition party voters into a smaller number of districts, which reduces their influence in other districts.
4. This is done by redrawing district lines so that they pass through neighborhoods with concentrated support for the opposition party.
5. The result is that the political party in control of redistricting can maintain power, even with fewer total votes.
